column2: THE ARABIAN NIGHTS
column3: THE ARABIAN NIGHTS

column2: _All nations have their fairy tales, but India seems to have been the country from which they all started, carried on their travels by the professional story-tellers who kept the tales alive throughout Asia.
column3: underscore All nations have their fairy tales, but India seems to have been the country from which they all started, carried on their travels by the professional story tellers who kept the tales alive throughout Asia.

column2: In Bagdad and Cairo to-day, that cafe never lacks customers where the blind storyteller relates to the spell-bound Arabs some chapter from the immortal Arabian Nights, the King of all Wonder Books.
column3: In Bagdad and Cairo to day, that cafe never lacks customers where the blind storyteller relates to the spell bound Arabs some chapter from the immortal Arabian Nights, the King of all Wonder Books.

column2: No one knows where the tales were written, except that they came out of the Far East, India, Arabia and Persia.
column3: No one knows where the tales were written, except that they came out of the Far East, India, Arabia and Persia.

column2: Haroun Al Raschid, who was called The Just, was a real Eastern monarch who lived in Bagdad over eleven hundred years ago, about the same time that Charlemagne was King of France.
column3: Haroun Al Raschid, who was called The Just, was a real Eastern monarch who lived in Bagdad over eleven hundred years ago, about the same time that Charlemagne was King of France.

column2: We can believe that the tales are very old, but the most we know is that they were translated from Arabic into French in 1704-17 by a Frenchman named Galland, and that the manuscript of his translation is preserved in the French National Library.
column3: We can believe that the tales are very old, but the most we know is that they were translated from Arabic into French in seventeen o four to seventeen by a Frenchman named Galland, and that the manuscript of his translation is preserved in the French National Library.

column2: ALI BABA AND THE FORTY THIEVES
column3: ALI BABA AND THE FORTY THIEVES

column2: There once lived in a town of Persia two brothers, one named Cassim, and the other Ali Baba.
column3: There once lived in a town of Persia two brothers, one named Cassim, and the other Ali Baba.

column2: Their father divided a small inheritance equally between them.
column3: Their father divided a small inheritance equally between them.

column2: Cassim married a very rich wife, and became a wealthy merchant.
column3: Cassim married a very rich wife, and became a wealthy merchant.

column2: Ali Baba married a woman as poor as himself, and lived by cutting wood, and bringing it upon three asses into the town to sell.
column3: Ali Baba married a woman as poor as himself, and lived by cutting wood, and bringing it upon three asses into the town to sell.

column2: One day, when Ali Baba was in the forest, and had just cut wood enough to load his asses, he saw at a distance a great cloud of dust, which seemed to approach him.
column3: One day, when Ali Baba was in the forest, and had just cut wood enough to load his asses, he saw at a distance a great cloud of dust, which seemed to approach him.

column2: He observed it with attention, and distinguished soon after a body of horsemen, whom he suspected might be robbers.
column3: He observed it with attention, and distinguished soon after a body of horsemen, whom he suspected might be robbers.

column2: He determined to leave his asses to save himself.
column3: He determined to leave his asses to save himself.

column2: He climbed up a large tree, planted on a high rock, whose branches were thick enough to conceal him, and yet enabled him to see all that passed without being discovered.
column3: He climbed up a large tree, planted on a high rock, whose branches were thick enough to conceal him, and yet enabled him to see all that passed without being discovered.

column2: The troop, who were to the number of forty, all well mounted and armed, came to the foot of the rock on which the tree stood, and there dismounted.
column3: The troop, who were to the number of forty, all well mounted and armed, came to the foot of the rock on which the tree stood, and there dismounted.

column2: Every man unbridled his horse, tied him to some shrub, and hung about his neck a bag of corn which they brought behind them.
column3: Every man unbridled his horse, tied him to some shrub, and hung about his neck a bag of corn which they brought behind them.

column2: Then each of them took off his saddle-bag, which seemed to Ali Baba to be full of gold and silver from its weight. One, whom he took to be their captain, came under the tree in which Ali Baba was concealed; and, making his way through some shrubs, pronounced these words--"Open, Sesame!" As soon as the captain of the robbers had thus spoken, a door opened in the rock; and after he had made all his troop enter before him, he followed them, when the door shut again of itself.
column3: Then each of them took off his saddle bag, which seemed to Ali Baba to be full of gold and silver from its weight. One, whom he took to be their captain, came under the tree in which Ali Baba was concealed; and, making his way through some shrubs, pronounced these words-"Open, Sesame!" As soon as the captain of the robbers had thus spoken, a door opened in the rock; and after he had made all his troop enter before him, he followed them, when the door shut again of itself.

column2: The robbers stayed some time within the rock, during which Ali Baba, fearful of being caught, remained in the tree.
column3: The robbers stayed some time within the rock, during which Ali Baba, fearful of being caught, remained in the tree.

column2: At last the door opened again, and as the captain went in last, so he came out first, and stood to see them all pass by him; when Ali Baba heard him make the door close by pronouncing these words, "Shut, Sesame!" Every man at once went and bridled his horse, fastened his wallet, and mounted again.
column3: At last the door opened again, and as the captain went in last, so he came out first, and stood to see them all pass by him; when Ali Baba heard him make the door close by pronouncing these words, "Shut, Sesame!" Every man at once went and bridled his horse, fastened his wallet, and mounted again.

column2: When the captain saw them all ready, he put himself at their head, and they returned the way they had come.
column3: When the captain saw them all ready, he put himself at their head, and they returned the way they had come.

column2: Ali Baba followed them with his eyes as far as he could see them, and afterward stayed a considerable time before he descended. Remembering the words the captain of the robbers used to cause the door to open and shut, he had the curiosity to try if his pronouncing them would have the same effect.
column3: Ali Baba followed them with his eyes as far as he could see them, and afterward stayed a considerable time before he descended. Remembering the words the captain of the robbers used to cause the door to open and shut, he had the curiosity to try if his pronouncing them would have the same effect.

column2: Accordingly, he went among the shrubs, and perceiving the door concealed behind them, stood before it and said, "Open, Sesame!"
column3: Accordingly, he went among the shrubs, and perceiving the door concealed behind them, stood before it and said, "Open, Sesame!"

column2: The door instantly flew wide open.
column3: The door instantly flew wide open.

column2: Ali Baba, who expected a dark, dismal cavern, was surprised to see a well-lighted and spacious chamber, which received the light from an opening at the top of the rock, and in which were all sorts of provisions, rich bales of silk, stuff, brocade, and valuable carpeting, piled upon one another, gold and silver ingots in great heaps, and money in bags.
column3: Ali Baba, who expected a dark, dismal cavern, was surprised to see a well lighted and spacious chamber, which received the light from an opening at the top of the rock, and in which were all sorts of provisions, rich bales of silk, stuff, brocade, and valuable carpeting, piled upon one another, gold and silver ingots in great heaps, and money in bags.

column2: The sight of all these riches made him suppose that this cave must have been occupied for ages by robbers, who had succeeded one another.
column3: The sight of all these riches made him suppose that this cave must have been occupied for ages by robbers, who had succeeded one another.

column2: Ali Baba went boldly into the cave, and collected as much of the gold coin, which was in bags, as he thought his three asses could carry.
column3: Ali Baba went boldly into the cave, and collected as much of the gold coin, which was in bags, as he thought his three asses could carry.

column2: When he had loaded them with the bags, he laid wood over them in such a manner that they could not be seen.
column3: When he had loaded them with the bags, he laid wood over them in such a manner that they could not be seen.

column2: When he had passed in and out as often as he wished, he stood before the door, and pronouncing the words, "Shut, Sesame!" the door closed of itself.
column3: When he had passed in and out as often as he wished, he stood before the door, and pronouncing the words, "Shut, Sesame!" the door closed of itself.

column2: He then made the best of his way to town.
column3: He then made the best of his way to town.

column2: When Ali Baba got home, he drove his asses into a little yard, shut the gates very carefully, threw off the wood that covered the panniers, carried the bags into the house, and ranged them in order before his wife.
column3: When Ali Baba got home, he drove his asses into a little yard, shut the gates very carefully, threw off the wood that covered the panniers, carried the bags into the house, and ranged them in order before his wife.

column2: He then emptied the bags, which raised such a great heap of gold as dazzled his wife's eyes, and then he told her the whole adventure from beginning to end, and, above all, recommended her to keep it secret.
column3: He then emptied the bags, which raised such a great heap of gold as dazzled his wife's eyes, and then he told her the whole adventure from beginning to end, and, above all, recommended her to keep it secret.

column2: The wife rejoiced greatly at their good-fortune, and would count all the gold piece by piece.
column3: The wife rejoiced greatly at their good fortune, and would count all the gold piece by piece.

column2: Wife, replied Ali Baba, "you do not know what you undertake, when you pretend to count the money; you will never have done.
column3: Wife, replied Ali Baba, "you do not know what you undertake, when you pretend to count the money; you will never have done.

column2: I will dig a hole and bury it.
column3: I will dig a hole and bury it.

column2: There is no time to be lost." "You are in the right, husband," replied she; "but let us know, as nigh as possible, how much we have.
column3: There is no time to be lost." "You are in the right, husband," replied she; "but let us know, as nigh as possible, how much we have.

column2: I will borrow a small measure, and measure it while you dig the hole."
column3: I will borrow a small measure, and measure it while you dig the hole."

column2: Away the wife ran to her brother-in-law Cassim, who lived just by, and, addressing herself to his wife, desired her to lend her a measure for a little while.
column3: Away the wife ran to her brother in law Cassim, who lived just by, and, addressing herself to his wife, desired her to lend her a measure for a little while.

column2: Her sister-in-law asked her whether she would have a great or a small one.
column3: Her sister in law asked her whether she would have a great or a small one.

column2: The other asked for a small one.
column3: The other asked for a small one.

column2: She bade her stay a little, and she would readily fetch one.
column3: She bade her stay a little, and she would readily fetch one.

column2: The sister-in-law did so, but as she knew Ali Baba's poverty, she was curious to know what sort of grain his wife wanted to measure, and, artfully putting some suet at the bottom of the measure, brought it to her, with the excuse that she was sorry that she had made her stay so long, but that she could not find it sooner.
column3: The sister in law did so, but as she knew Ali Baba's poverty, she was curious to know what sort of grain his wife wanted to measure, and, artfully putting some suet at the bottom of the measure, brought it to her, with the excuse that she was sorry that she had made her stay so long, but that she could not find it sooner.

column2: Ali Baba's wife went home, set the measure upon the heap of gold, filled it, and emptied it often upon the sofa, till she had done, when she was very well satisfied to find the number of measures amounted to so many as they did, and went to tell her husband, who had almost finished digging the hole.
column3: Ali Baba's wife went home, set the measure upon the heap of gold, filled it, and emptied it often upon the sofa, till she had done, when she was very well satisfied to find the number of measures amounted to so many as they did, and went to tell her husband, who had almost finished digging the hole.

column2: While Ali Baba was burying the gold, his wife, to show her exactness and diligence to her sister-in-law, carried the measure back again, but without taking notice that a piece of gold had stuck to the bottom.
column3: While Ali Baba was burying the gold, his wife, to show her exactness and diligence to her sister in law, carried the measure back again, but without taking notice that a piece of gold had stuck to the bottom.

column2: Sister, said she, giving it to her again, "you see that I have not kept your measure long.
column3: Sister, said she, giving it to her again, "you see that I have not kept your measure long.

column2: I am obliged to you for it, and return it with thanks."
column3: I am obliged to you for it, and return it with thanks."

column2: As soon as Ali Baba's wife was gone, Cassim's wife looked at the bottom of the measure, and was in inexpressible surprise to find a piece of gold sticking to it.
column3: As soon as Ali Baba's wife was gone, Cassim's wife looked at the bottom of the measure, and was in inexpressible surprise to find a piece of gold sticking to it.

column2: Envy immediately possessed her breast.
column3: Envy immediately possessed her breast.

column2: What! said she, "has Ali Baba gold so plentiful as to measure it?
column3: What! said she, "has Ali Baba gold so plentiful as to measure it?

column2: Whence has he all this wealth?"
column3: Whence has he all this wealth?"

column2: Cassim, her husband, was at his counting-house.
column3: Cassim, her husband, was at his counting house.

column2: When he came home his wife said to him, "Cassim, I know you think yourself rich, but Ali Baba is infinitely richer than you.
column3: When he came home his wife said to him, "Cassim, I know you think yourself rich, but Ali Baba is infinitely richer than you.

column2: He does not count his money, but measures it." Cassim desired her to explain the riddle, which she did by telling him the stratagem she had used to make the discovery, and showed him the piece of money, which was so old that they could not tell in what prince's reign it was coined.
column3: He does not count his money, but measures it." Cassim desired her to explain the riddle, which she did by telling him the stratagem she had used to make the discovery, and showed him the piece of money, which was so old that they could not tell in what prince's reign it was coined.

column2: Cassim, after he had married the rich widow, had never treated Ali Baba as a brother, but neglected him; and now, instead of being pleased, he conceived a base envy at his brother's prosperity.
column3: Cassim, after he had married the rich widow, had never treated Ali Baba as a brother, but neglected him; and now, instead of being pleased, he conceived a base envy at his brother's prosperity.

column2: He could not sleep all that night, and went to him in the morning before sunrise.
column3: He could not sleep all that night, and went to him in the morning before sunrise.

column2: Ali Baba, said he, "I am surprised at you!
column3: Ali Baba, said he, "I am surprised at you!

column2: you pretend to be miserably poor, and yet you measure gold.

column2: My wife found this at the bottom of the measure you borrowed yesterday."
column3: My wife found this at the bottom of the measure you borrowed yesterday."

column2: By this discourse, Ali Baba perceived that Cassim and his wife, through his own wife's folly, knew what they had so much reason to conceal; but what was done could not be undone.
column3: By this discourse, Ali Baba perceived that Cassim and his wife, through his own wife's folly, knew what they had so much reason to conceal; but what was done could not be undone.

column2: Therefore, without showing the least surprise or trouble, he confessed all, and offered his brother part of his treasure to keep the secret.
column3: Therefore, without showing the least surprise or trouble, he confessed all, and offered his brother part of his treasure to keep the secret.

column2: I expect as much, replied Cassim haughtily; "but I must know exactly where this treasure is, and how I may visit it myself when I choose; otherwise, I will go and inform against you, and then you will not only get no more, but will lose all you have, and I shall have a share for my information."
column3: I expect as much, replied Cassim haughtily; "but I must know exactly where this treasure is, and how I may visit it myself when I choose; otherwise, I will go and inform against you, and then you will not only get no more, but will lose all you have, and I shall have a share for my information."

column2: Ali Baba told him all he desired, even to the very words he was to use to gain admission into the cave.
column3: Ali Baba told him all he desired, even to the very words he was to use to gain admission into the cave.

column2: Cassim rose the next morning long before the sun, and set out for the forest with ten mules bearing great chests, which he designed to fill, and followed the road which Ali Baba had pointed out to him.
column3: Cassim rose the next morning long before the sun, and set out for the forest with ten mules bearing great chests, which he designed to fill, and followed the road which Ali Baba had pointed out to him.

column2: It was not long before he reached the rock, and found out the place, by the tree and other marks which his brother had given him.
column3: It was not long before he reached the rock, and found out the place, by the tree and other marks which his brother had given him.

column2: When he reached the entrance of the cavern, he pronounced the words, "Open, Sesame!" The door immediately opened, and when he was in, closed upon him.
column3: When he reached the entrance of the cavern, he pronounced the words, "Open, Sesame!" The door immediately opened, and when he was in, closed upon him.

column2: On examining the cave, he was in great admiration to find much more riches than he had expected from Ali Baba's relation.
column3: On examining the cave, he was in great admiration to find much more riches than he had expected from Ali Baba's relation.

column2: He quickly laid as many bags of gold as he could carry at the door of the cavern; but his thoughts were so full of the great riches he should possess, that he could not think of the necessary word to make it open, and instead of "Sesame" said, "Open, Barley!" and was much amazed to find that the door remained fast shut.
column3: He quickly laid as many bags of gold as he could carry at the door of the cavern; but his thoughts were so full of the great riches he should possess, that he could not think of the necessary word to make it open, and instead of "Sesame" said, "Open, Barley!" and was much amazed to find that the door remained fast shut.

column2: He named several sorts of grain, but still the door would not open.
column3: He named several sorts of grain, but still the door would not open.

column2: Cassim had never expected such an incident, and was so alarmed at the danger he was in, that the more he endeavored to remember the word "Sesame," the more his memory was confounded, and he had as much forgotten it as if he had never heard it mentioned, He threw down the bags he had loaded himself with, and walked distractedly up and down the cave, without having the least regard to the riches that were round him.
column3: Cassim had never expected such an incident, and was so alarmed at the danger he was in, that the more he endeavored to remember the word "Sesame," the more his memory was confounded, and he had as much forgotten it as if he had never heard it mentioned, He threw down the bags he had loaded himself with, and walked distractedly up and down the cave, without having the least regard to the riches that were round him.

column2: About noon the robbers visited their cave.
column3: About noon the robbers visited their cave.

column2: At some distance they saw Cassim's mules straggling about the rock, with great chests on their backs.
column3: At some distance they saw Cassim's mules straggling about the rock, with great chests on their backs.

column2: Alarmed at this, they galloped full speed to the cave.
column3: Alarmed at this, they galloped full speed to the cave.

column2: They drove away the mules, who strayed through the forest so far that they were soon out of sight, and went directly, with their naked sabres in their hands, to the door, which, on their captain pronouncing the proper words, immediately opened.
column3: They drove away the mules, who strayed through the forest so far that they were soon out of sight, and went directly, with their naked sabres in their hands, to the door, which, on their captain pronouncing the proper words, immediately opened.

column2: Cassim, who heard the noise of the horses' feet, at once guessed the arrival of the robbers, and resolved to make one effort for his life.
column3: Cassim, who heard the noise of the horses' feet, at once guessed the arrival of the robbers, and resolved to make one effort for his life.

column2: He rushed to the door, and no sooner saw the door open, than he ran out and threw the leader down, but could not escape the other robbers, who with their cimeters soon deprived him of life.
column3: He rushed to the door, and no sooner saw the door open, than he ran out and threw the leader down, but could not escape the other robbers, who with their cimeters soon deprived him of life.

column2: The first care of the robbers after this was to examine the cave. They found all the bags which Cassim had brought to the door, to be ready to load his mules, and carried them again to their places, but they did not miss what Ali Baba had taken away before. Then holding a council, and deliberating upon this occurrence, they guessed that Cassim, when he was in, could not get out again, but could not imagine how he had learned the secret words by which alone he could enter.
column3: The first care of the robbers after this was to examine the cave. They found all the bags which Cassim had brought to the door, to be ready to load his mules, and carried them again to their places, but they did not miss what Ali Baba had taken away before. Then holding a council, and deliberating upon this occurrence, they guessed that Cassim, when he was in, could not get out again, but could not imagine how he had learned the secret words by which alone he could enter.

column2: They could not deny the fact of his being there; and to terrify any person or accomplice who should attempt the same thing, they agreed to cut Cassim's body into four quarters--to hang two on one side, and two on the other, within the door of the cave.
column3: They could not deny the fact of his being there; and to terrify any person or accomplice who should attempt the same thing, they agreed to cut Cassim's body into four quarters-to hang two on one side, and two on the other, within the door of the cave.

column2: They had no sooner taken this resolution than they put it in execution; and when they had nothing more to detain them, left the place of their hoards well closed.
column3: They had no sooner taken this resolution than they put it in execution; and when they had nothing more to detain them, left the place of their hoards well closed.

column2: They mounted their horses, went to beat the roads again, and to attack the caravans they might meet.
column3: They mounted their horses, went to beat the roads again, and to attack the caravans they might meet.

column2: In the meantime, Cassim's wife was very uneasy when night came, and her husband was not returned.
column3: In the meantime, Cassim's wife was very uneasy when night came, and her husband was not returned.

column2: She ran to Ali Baba in great alarm, and said: "I believe, brother-in-law, that you know Cassim is gone to the forest, and upon what account; it is now night, and he has not returned; I am afraid some misfortune has happened to him." Ali Baba told her that she need not frighten herself, for that certainly Cassim would not think it proper to come into the town till the night should be pretty far advanced.
column3: She ran to Ali Baba in great alarm, and said: "I believe, brother in law, that you know Cassim is gone to the forest, and upon what account; it is now night, and he has not returned; I am afraid some misfortune has happened to him." Ali Baba told her that she need not frighten herself, for that certainly Cassim would not think it proper to come into the town till the night should be pretty far advanced.

column2: Cassim's wife, considering how much it concerned her husband to keep the business secret, was the more easily persuaded to believe her brother-in-law.
column3: Cassim's wife, considering how much it concerned her husband to keep the business secret, was the more easily persuaded to believe her brother in law.

column2: She went home again, and waited patiently till midnight.
column3: She went home again, and waited patiently till midnight.

column2: Then her fear redoubled, and her grief was the more sensible because she was forced to keep it to herself.
column3: Then her fear redoubled, and her grief was the more sensible because she was forced to keep it to herself.

column2: She repented of her foolish curiosity, and cursed her desire of prying into the affairs of her brother and sister-in-law.
column3: She repented of her foolish curiosity, and cursed her desire of prying into the affairs of her brother and sister in law.

column2: She spent all the night in weeping; and, as soon as it was day, went to them, telling them, by her tears, the cause of her coming.
column3: She spent all the night in weeping; and, as soon as it was day, went to them, telling them, by her tears, the cause of her coming.

column2: Ali Baba did not wait for his sister-in-law to desire him to go to see what was become of Cassim, but departed immediately with his three asses, begging of her first to moderate her affliction.
column3: Ali Baba did not wait for his sister in law to desire him to go to see what was become of Cassim, but departed immediately with his three asses, begging of her first to moderate her affliction.

column2: He went to the forest, and when he came near the rock, having seen neither his brother nor the mules in his way, was seriously alarmed at finding some blood spilled near the door, which he took for an ill omen; but when he had pronounced the word, and the door had opened, he was struck with horror at the dismal sight of his brother's body.
column3: He went to the forest, and when he came near the rock, having seen neither his brother nor the mules in his way, was seriously alarmed at finding some blood spilled near the door, which he took for an ill omen; but when he had pronounced the word, and the door had opened, he was struck with horror at the dismal sight of his brother's body.

column2: He was not long in determining how he should pay the last dues to his brother; but without adverting to the little fraternal affection he had shown for him, went into the cave to find something to enshroud his remains; and having loaded one of his asses with them, covered them over with wood.
column3: He was not long in determining how he should pay the last dues to his brother; but without adverting to the little fraternal affection he had shown for him, went into the cave to find something to enshroud his remains; and having loaded one of his asses with them, covered them over with wood.

column2: The other two asses he loaded with bags of gold, covering them with wood also as before; and then bidding the door shut, came away; but was so cautious as to stop some time at the end of the forest, that he might not go into the town before night.
column3: The other two asses he loaded with bags of gold, covering them with wood also as before; and then bidding the door shut, came away; but was so cautious as to stop some time at the end of the forest, that he might not go into the town before night.

column2: When he came home, he drove the two asses loaded with gold into his little yard, and left the care of unloading them to his wife, while he led the other to his sister-in-law's house.
column3: When he came home, he drove the two asses loaded with gold into his little yard, and left the care of unloading them to his wife, while he led the other to his sister in law's house.

column2: Ali Baba knocked at the door, which was opened by Morgiana, a clever, intelligent slave, who was fruitful in inventions to meet the most difficult circumstances.
column3: Ali Baba knocked at the door, which was opened by Morgiana, a clever, intelligent slave, who was fruitful in inventions to meet the most difficult circumstances.

column2: When he came into the court, he unloaded the ass, and taking Morgiana aside, said to her: "You must observe an inviolable secrecy.
column3: When he came into the court, he unloaded the ass, and taking Morgiana aside, said to her: "You must observe an inviolable secrecy.

column2: Your master's body is contained in these two panniers.
column3: Your master's body is contained in these two panniers.

column2: We must bury him as if he had died a natural death.
column3: We must bury him as if he had died a natural death.

column2: Go now and tell your mistress.
column3: Go now and tell your mistress.

column2: I leave the matter to your wit and skilful devices."
column3: I leave the matter to your wit and skilful devices."

column2: Ali Baba helped to place the body in Cassim's house, again recommended to Morgiana to act her part well, and then returned with his ass.
column3: Ali Baba helped to place the body in Cassim's house, again recommended to Morgiana to act her part well, and then returned with his ass.

column2: Morgiana went out, early the next morning to a druggist, and asked for a sort of lozenge which was considered efficacious in the most dangerous disorders.
column3: Morgiana went out, early the next morning to a druggist, and asked for a sort of lozenge which was considered efficacious in the most dangerous disorders.

column2: The apothecary inquired who was ill.
column3: The apothecary inquired who was ill.

column2: She replied, with a sigh, Her good master, Cassim himself, and that he could neither eat nor speak.
column3: She replied, with a sigh, Her good master, Cassim himself, and that he could neither eat nor speak.

column2: In the evening Morgiana went to the same druggist's again, and with tears in her eyes, asked for an essence which they used to give to sick people only when at the last extremity.
column3: In the evening Morgiana went to the same druggist's again, and with tears in her eyes, asked for an essence which they used to give to sick people only when at the last extremity.

column2: Alas! said she, taking it from the apothecary, "I am afraid that this remedy will have no better effect than the lozenges; and that I shall lose my good master."
column3: Alas! said she, taking it from the apothecary, "I am afraid that this remedy will have no better effect than the lozenges; and that I shall lose my good master."

column2: On the other hand, as Ali Baba and his wife were often seen to go between Cassim's and their own house all that day, and to seem melancholy, nobody was surprised in the evening to hear the lamentable shrieks and cries of Cassim's wife and Morgiana, who gave out everywhere that her master was dead.
column3: On the other hand, as Ali Baba and his wife were often seen to go between Cassim's and their own house all that day, and to seem melancholy, nobody was surprised in the evening to hear the lamentable shrieks and cries of Cassim's wife and Morgiana, who gave out everywhere that her master was dead.

column2: The next morning at daybreak, Morgiana went to an old cobbler whom she knew to be always early at his stall, and bidding him good-morrow, put a piece of gold into his hand, saying, "Baba Mustapha, you must bring with you your sewing tackle, and come with me; but I must tell you, I shall blindfold you when you come to such a place."
column3: The next morning at daybreak, Morgiana went to an old cobbler whom she knew to be always early at his stall, and bidding him good morrow, put a piece of gold into his hand, saying, "Baba Mustapha, you must bring with you your sewing tackle, and come with me; but I must tell you, I shall blindfold you when you come to such a place."

column2: Baba Mustapha seemed to hesitate a little at these words.
column3: Baba Mustapha seemed to hesitate a little at these words.

column2: Oh! oh! replied he, "you must have me do something against my conscience, or against my honor?" "God forbid," said Morgiana, putting another piece of gold into his hand, "that I should ask anything that is contrary to your honor! only come along with me and fear nothing."
column3: Oh! oh! replied he, "you must have me do something against my conscience, or against my honor?" "God forbid," said Morgiana, putting another piece of gold into his hand, "that I should ask anything that is contrary to your honor! only come along with me and fear nothing."

column2: Baba Mustapha went with Morgiana, who, after she had bound his eyes with a handkerchief at the place she had mentioned, conveyed him to her deceased master's house, and never unloosed his eyes till he had entered the room where she had put the corpse together.
column3: Baba Mustapha went with Morgiana, who, after she had bound his eyes with a handkerchief at the place she had mentioned, conveyed him to her deceased master's house, and never unloosed his eyes till he had entered the room where she had put the corpse together.

column2: Baba Mustapha, said she, "you must make haste and sew the parts of this body together; and when you have done, I will give you another piece of gold."
column3: Baba Mustapha, said she, "you must make haste and sew the parts of this body together; and when you have done, I will give you another piece of gold."

column2: After Baba Mustapha had finished his task, she blindfolded him again, gave him the third piece of gold as she had promised, and recommending secrecy to him, carried him back to the place where she first bound his eyes, pulled off the bandage, and let him go home, but watched him that he returned toward his stall, till he was quite out of sight, for fear he should have the curiosity to return and dodge her; she then went home.
column3: After Baba Mustapha had finished his task, she blindfolded him again, gave him the third piece of gold as she had promised, and recommending secrecy to him, carried him back to the place where she first bound his eyes, pulled off the bandage, and let him go home, but watched him that he returned toward his stall, till he was quite out of sight, for fear he should have the curiosity to return and dodge her; she then went home.

column2: Morgiana, on her return, warmed some water to wash the body, and at the same time Ali Baba perfumed it with incense, and wrapped it in the burying clothes with the accustomed ceremonies.
column3: Morgiana, on her return, warmed some water to wash the body, and at the same time Ali Baba perfumed it with incense, and wrapped it in the burying clothes with the accustomed ceremonies.

column2: Not long after, the proper officer brought the bier, and when the attendants of the mosque, whose business it was to wash the dead, offered to perform their duty, she told them that it was done already.
column3: Not long after, the proper officer brought the bier, and when the attendants of the mosque, whose business it was to wash the dead, offered to perform their duty, she told them that it was done already.

column2: Shortly after this the imaun and the other ministers of the mosque arrived.
column3: Shortly after this the imaun and the other ministers of the mosque arrived.

column2: Four neighbors carried the corpse to the burying ground, following the imaun, who recited some prayers.
column3: Four neighbors carried the corpse to the burying ground, following the imaun, who recited some prayers.

column2: Ali Baba came after with some neighbors, who often relieved the others in carrying the bier to the burying ground.
column3: Ali Baba came after with some neighbors, who often relieved the others in carrying the bier to the burying ground.

column2: Morgiana, a slave to the deceased, followed in the procession, weeping, beating her breast, and tearing her hair. Cassim's wife stayed at home mourning, uttering lamentable cries with the women of the neighborhood, who came, according to custom, during the funeral, and, joining their lamentations with hers, filled the quarter far and near with sounds of sorrow.
column3: Morgiana, a slave to the deceased, followed in the procession, weeping, beating her breast, and tearing her hair. Cassim's wife stayed at home mourning, uttering lamentable cries with the women of the neighborhood, who came, according to custom, during the funeral, and, joining their lamentations with hers, filled the quarter far and near with sounds of sorrow.

column2: In this manner Cassim's melancholy death was concealed, and hushed up between Ali Baba, his widow, and Morgiana, his slave, with so much contrivance that nobody in the city had the least knowledge or suspicion of the cause of it.
column3: In this manner Cassim's melancholy death was concealed, and hushed up between Ali Baba, his widow, and Morgiana, his slave, with so much contrivance that nobody in the city had the least knowledge or suspicion of the cause of it.

column2: Three or four days after the funeral, Ali Baba removed his few goods openly to his sister-in- law's house, in which it was agreed that he should in future live; but the money he had taken from the robbers he conveyed thither by night.
column3: Three or four days after the funeral, Ali Baba removed his few goods openly to his sister in law's house, in which it was agreed that he should in future live; but the money he had taken from the robbers he conveyed thither by night.

column2: As for Cassim's warehouse, he intrusted it entirely to the management of his eldest son.
column3: As for Cassim's warehouse, he intrusted it entirely to the management of his eldest son.

column2: While these things were being done, the forty robbers again visited their retreat in the forest.
column3: While these things were being done, the forty robbers again visited their retreat in the forest.

column2: Great, then, was their surprise to find Cassim's body taken away, with some of their bags of gold.
column3: Great, then, was their surprise to find Cassim's body taken away, with some of their bags of gold.

column2: We are certainly discovered, said the captain.
column3: We are certainly discovered, said the captain.

column2: The removal of the body and the loss of some of our money plainly show that the man whom we killed had an accomplice; and for our own lives' sake we must try and find him.	The removal of the body and the loss of some of our money plainly show that the man whom we killed had an accomplice; and for our own lives' sake we must try and find him.
column3: true

column2: What say you, my lads?"
column3: What say you, my lads?"

column2: All the robbers unanimously approved of the captain's proposal.
column3: All the robbers unanimously approved of the captain's proposal.

column2: Well, said the captain, "one of you, the boldest and most skilful among you, must go into the town, disguised as a traveller and a stranger, to try if he can hear any talk of the man whom we have killed, and endeavor to find out who he was, and where he lived.
column3: Well, said the captain, "one of you, the boldest and most skilful among you, must go into the town, disguised as a traveller and a stranger, to try if he can hear any talk of the man whom we have killed, and endeavor to find out who he was, and where he lived.

column2: This is a matter of the first importance, and for fear of any treachery, I propose that whoever undertakes this business without success, even though the failure arises only from an error of judgment, shall suffer death."
column3: This is a matter of the first importance, and for fear of any treachery, I propose that whoever undertakes this business without success, even though the failure arises only from an error of judgment, shall suffer death."

column2: Without waiting for the sentiments of his companions, one of the robbers started up, and said, "I submit to this condition, and think it an honor to expose my life to serve the troop."
column3: Without waiting for the sentiments of his companions, one of the robbers started up, and said, "I submit to this condition, and think it an honor to expose my life to serve the troop."

column2: After this robber had received great commendations from the captain and his comrades, he disguised himself so that nobody would take him for what he was; and taking his leave of the troop that night, went into the town just at daybreak, and walked up and down, till accidentally he came to Baba Mustapha's stall, which was always open before any of the shops.
column3: After this robber had received great commendations from the captain and his comrades, he disguised himself so that nobody would take him for what he was; and taking his leave of the troop that night, went into the town just at daybreak, and walked up and down, till accidentally he came to Baba Mustapha's stall, which was always open before any of the shops.

column2: Baba Mustapha was seated with an awl in his hand, just going to work.
column3: Baba Mustapha was seated with an awl in his hand, just going to work.

column2: The robber saluted him, bidding him good-morrow; and, perceiving that he was old, said, "Honest man, you begin to work very early: is it possible that one of your age can see so well?
column3: The robber saluted him, bidding him good morrow; and, perceiving that he was old, said, "Honest man, you begin to work very early: is it possible that one of your age can see so well?

column2: I question, even if it were somewhat lighter, whether you could see to stitch."
column3: I question, even if it were somewhat lighter, whether you could see to stitch."

column2: You do not know me, replied Baba Mustapha; "for old as I am, I have extraordinary good eyes; and you will not doubt it when I tell you that I sewed the body of a dead man together in a place where I had not so much light as I have now."
column3: You do not know me, replied Baba Mustapha; "for old as I am, I have extraordinary good eyes; and you will not doubt it when I tell you that I sewed the body of a dead man together in a place where I had not so much light as I have now."

column2: A dead body! exclaimed the robber, with affected amazement. "Yes, yes," answered Baba Mustapha; "I see you want to have me speak out, but you shall know no more."
column3: A dead body! exclaimed the robber, with affected amazement. "Yes, yes," answered Baba Mustapha; "I see you want to have me speak out, but you shall know no more."

column2: The robber felt sure that he had discovered what he sought.
column3: The robber felt sure that he had discovered what he sought.

column2: He pulled out a piece of gold, and putting it into Baba Mustapha's hand, said to him, "I do not want to learn your secret, though I can assume you you might safely trust me with it.
column3: He pulled out a piece of gold, and putting it into Baba Mustapha's hand, said to him, "I do not want to learn your secret, though I can assume you you might safely trust me with it.

column2: The only thing I desire of you is to show me the house where you stitched up the dead body."
column3: The only thing I desire of you is to show me the house where you stitched up the dead body."

column2: If I were disposed to do you that favor, replied Baba Mustapha, "I assure you I cannot.
column3: If I were disposed to do you that favor, replied Baba Mustapha, "I assure you I cannot.

column2: I was taken to a certain place, whence I was led blindfold to the house, and afterward brought back again in the same manner; you see, therefore, the impossibility of my doing what you desire."
column3: I was taken to a certain place, whence I was led blindfold to the house, and afterward brought back again in the same manner; you see, therefore, the impossibility of my doing what you desire."

column2: Well, replied the robber, "you may, however, remember a little of the way that you were led blindfold.
column3: Well, replied the robber, "you may, however, remember a little of the way that you were led blindfold.

column2: Come, let me blind your eyes at the same place.
column3: Come, let me blind your eyes at the same place.

column2: We will walk together; perhaps you may recognize some part; and as everybody ought to be paid for their trouble, there is another piece of gold for you; gratify me in what I ask you." So saying, he put another piece of gold into his hand.
column3: We will walk together; perhaps you may recognize some part; and as everybody ought to be paid for their trouble, there is another piece of gold for you; gratify me in what I ask you." So saying, he put another piece of gold into his hand.

column2: The two pieces of gold were great temptations to Baba Mustapha.
column3: The two pieces of gold were great temptations to Baba Mustapha.

column2: He looked at them a long time in his hand without saying a word, but at last he pulled out his purse and put them in.
column3: He looked at them a long time in his hand without saying a word, but at last he pulled out his purse and put them in.

column2: I cannot promise, said he to the robber, "that I can remember the way exactly; but since you desire, I will try what I can do." At these words Baba Mustapha rose up, to the great joy of the robber, and led him to the place where Morgiana had bound his eyes.
column3: I cannot promise, said he to the robber, "that I can remember the way exactly; but since you desire, I will try what I can do." At these words Baba Mustapha rose up, to the great joy of the robber, and led him to the place where Morgiana had bound his eyes.

column2: It was here, said Baba Mustapha, "I was blindfolded; and I turned this way." The robber tied his handkerchief over his eyes, and walked by him till they stopped directly at Cassim's house, where Ali Baba then lived.
column3: It was here, said Baba Mustapha, "I was blindfolded; and I turned this way." The robber tied his handkerchief over his eyes, and walked by him till they stopped directly at Cassim's house, where Ali Baba then lived.

column2: The thief, before he pulled off the band, marked the door with a piece of chalk, which he had ready in his hand, and then asked him if he knew whose house that was; to which Baba Mustapha replied, that as he did not live in that neighborhood he could not tell.
column3: The thief, before he pulled off the band, marked the door with a piece of chalk, which he had ready in his hand, and then asked him if he knew whose house that was; to which Baba Mustapha replied, that as he did not live in that neighborhood he could not tell.

column2: The robber, finding he could discover no more from Baba Mustapha, thanked him for the trouble he had taken, and left him to go back to his stall, while he returned to the forest, persuaded that he should be very well received.
column3: The robber, finding he could discover no more from Baba Mustapha, thanked him for the trouble he had taken, and left him to go back to his stall, while he returned to the forest, persuaded that he should be very well received.

column2: A little after the robber and Baba Mustapha had parted, Morgiana went out of Ali Baba's house upon some errand, and upon her return, seeing the mark the robber had made, stopped to observe it.
column3: A little after the robber and Baba Mustapha had parted, Morgiana went out of Ali Baba's house upon some errand, and upon her return, seeing the mark the robber had made, stopped to observe it.

column2: What can be the meaning of this mark? said she to herself; "somebody intends my master no good: however, with whatever intention it was done, it is advisable to guard against the worst." Accordingly, she fetched a piece of chalk, and marked two or three doors on each side, in the same manner, without saying a word to her master or mistress.
column3: What can be the meaning of this mark? said she to herself; "somebody intends my master no good: however, with whatever intention it was done, it is advisable to guard against the worst." Accordingly, she fetched a piece of chalk, and marked two or three doors on each side, in the same manner, without saying a word to her master or mistress.

column2: In the meantime, the robber rejoined his troop in the forest, and recounted to them his success, expatiating upon his good fortune in meeting so soon with the only person who could inform him of what he wanted to know.
column3: In the meantime, the robber rejoined his troop in the forest, and recounted to them his success, expatiating upon his good fortune in meeting so soon with the only person who could inform him of what he wanted to know.

column2: All the robbers listened to him with the utmost satisfaction; when the captain, after commending his diligence, addressing himself to them all, said, "Comrades, we have no time to lose: let us set off well armed, without its appearing who we are; but that we may not excite any suspicion, let only one or two go into the town together, and join at our rendezvous, which shall be the great square.
column3: All the robbers listened to him with the utmost satisfaction; when the captain, after commending his diligence, addressing himself to them all, said, "Comrades, we have no time to lose: let us set off well armed, without its appearing who we are; but that we may not excite any suspicion, let only one or two go into the town together, and join at our rendezvous, which shall be the great square.

column2: In the meantime, our comrade who brought us the good news and I will go and find out the house, that we may consult what had best be done."
column3: In the meantime, our comrade who brought us the good news and I will go and find out the house, that we may consult what had best be done."

column2: This speech and plan were approved of by all, and they were soon ready.
column3: This speech and plan were approved of by all, and they were soon ready.

column2: They filed off in parties of two each, after some interval of time, and got into the town without being in the least suspected.
column3: They filed off in parties of two each, after some interval of time, and got into the town without being in the least suspected.

column2: The captain, and he who had visited the town in the morning as spy, came in the last.
column3: The captain, and he who had visited the town in the morning as spy, came in the last.

column2: He led the captain into the street where he had marked Ali Baba's residence; and when they came to the first of the houses which Morgiana had marked, he pointed it out.
column3: He led the captain into the street where he had marked Ali Baba's residence; and when they came to the first of the houses which Morgiana had marked, he pointed it out.

column2: But the captain observed that the next door was chalked in the same manner, and in the same place; and showing it to his guide, asked him which house it was, that, or the first. The guide was so confounded that he knew not what answer to make, but still more puzzled when he and the captain saw five or six houses similarly marked.
column3: But the captain observed that the next door was chalked in the same manner, and in the same place; and showing it to his guide, asked him which house it was, that, or the first. The guide was so confounded that he knew not what answer to make, but still more puzzled when he and the captain saw five or six houses similarly marked.

column2: He assured the captain, with an oath, that he had marked but one, and could not tell who had chalked the rest, so that he could not distinguish the house which the cobbler had stopped at.
column3: He assured the captain, with an oath, that he had marked but one, and could not tell who had chalked the rest, so that he could not distinguish the house which the cobbler had stopped at.
